name: Van der Waerden number
rephrased: No matter how you color the integers from 1 to N using r different colors, if N is large enough (at least W(r,k)), you must find a monochromatic arithmetic progression of length k.
implication_form: If you color the integers from 1 to N using r colors, then there exists an arithmetic progression of length k consisting of integers all of the same color.
posed_by: Boudewijn de Rooij (alias Bart van der Waerden)
solved_by: partially solved (exact values known for small r and k, but general solution unknown)
explained: Van der Waerden's theorem states that for any positive integers r and k, there exists a positive integer N such that for any coloring of the integers {1, 2, ..., N} with r colors, there is a monochromatic arithmetic progression of length k. The van der Waerden number W(r, k) is defined as the smallest such N that guarantees this property regardless of the coloring.
